glossary.description: Broad categories of cloud computing environments based on ownership and access models.
Cloud infrastructure and services owned and operated by a third-party provider, offering resources over the internet to multiple customers (e.g., AWS, Azure, GCP).
Cloud infrastructure and services exclusively used by a single organization, either hosted on-premises or by a third-party. Provides greater control and customization.
A cloud model combining public and private clouds, linked by technology enabling data and applications to move between them, offering flexibility and choice.
Fundamental cloud service models differing in the level of control and management responsibility between user and provider.
Provides fundamental computing resources like virtual machines, storage, and networking. Users have maximum control over the infrastructure but are responsible for OS, middleware, applications.
Provides a managed environment for developing, running, and managing applications. Includes OS, middleware, runtime, etc. Developers focus on code.
Fully managed, subscription-based software applications delivered over the internet (e.g., Office 365, Salesforce, Gmail).
The processing power and memory resources required to execute workloads in a cloud environment.
Scalable on-demand virtual machines in Azure, allowing you to choose from various operating systems and configurations.
Manages and automatically scales multiple identical virtual machines, providing high availability and load balancing.
Utilize unused Azure compute capacity at deep discounts, ideal for interruptible workloads.
Delivers virtual desktops and applications, enabling remote work and secure access.
Fully managed platform to build, deploy, and scale web apps, APIs, and mobile backends.
Serverless compute service for event-driven code execution, enabling small, focused functions.
Quickly run containers in Azure without managing VMs or higher-level services.
Simplifies Kubernetes cluster deployment, scaling, and management in Azure.
Manages large-scale, parallel, and high-performance computing (HPC) workloads in Azure.
Cloud-based storage solutions for structured and unstructured data.
Fully managed relational database service based on SQL Server, offering high availability and scalability.
Globally distributed, multi-model database service enabling rapid development with various data models.
Fully managed MySQL database service in Azure.
Fully managed PostgreSQL database service in Azure.
Fully managed MariaDB database service in Azure.
In-memory data store for high-performance and scalable applications.
Run SQL Server workloads on Azure virtual machines for complete control over the database instance.
Various cloud-based options for storing different data types, each with specific use cases and characteristics.
Scalable object storage for unstructured data like images, videos, and documents.
Provides fully managed file shares accessible using industry-standard network protocols.
Reliable messaging service for storing and retrieving large numbers of messages.
NoSQL storage for storing structured, non-relational data.
Highly scalable and secure data repository designed for big data analytics workloads.
Components and services that facilitate communication within and outside of a cloud environment.
Enables secure connectivity between virtual networks and on-premises networks or other cloud providers.
Allows resources within a private subnet to connect to the internet without exposing their private IP addresses.
Represents your on-premises network for connecting to virtual networks in Azure.
Acts as a bridge, securely transferring data between on-premises data sources and Azure cloud services.

glossary.term: Azure Stack Edge / Data Box Gateway
glossary.description: Hardware appliances enabling data transfer to Azure with network acceleration and offline capabilities.
Tools and services for processing, analyzing, and deriving insights from large, complex datasets.
Cloud-based data warehouse and analytics service integrating data integration, enterprise data warehousing, and big data analytics.
Managed cloud service for open-source analytics frameworks like Hadoop, Spark, Kafka, and others.
Job-based analytics service for massively parallel data processing over large datasets.
Collaborative Apache Spark-based analytics platform optimized for Azure.
Fully managed data integration service for orchestrating and automating data movement and transformation.
Real-time analytics engine for processing and analyzing high-velocity data streams.
Services enabling the connection, management, and data analysis from large networks of internet-connected devices.
Centralized message hub for bi-directional device-to-cloud and cloud-to-device communication.
Fully managed SaaS platform simplifying IoT solution development and management.

A comprehensive IoT security solution from Microsoft, including specialized microcontrollers (MCUs), a custom Linux-based OS, and a cloud-based security service. It aims to provide end-to-end security for IoT devices
Software and resources used to design, build, test, and deploy applications on Azure. Includes Visual Studio Code, Azure SDKs, and Azure DevOps.

A cloud-based suite of tools for collaboration and software development. Provides services like version control (Git), continuous integration/continuous delivery (CI/CD) pipelines, project management, and testing.
A service for quickly creating development and test environments in Azure. Allows you to provision pre-configured environments, manage costs, and enforce policies.
The process and tools used to oversee the health, performance, and security of Azure resources and applications.
A centralized service for collecting, analyzing, and visualizing logs and metrics from Azure resources and applications. Provides insights into performance, usage, and potential issues.
Provides personalized recommendations to optimize Azure deployments for cost, performance, security, reliability, and operational excellence.
Gives you a personalized view of the health of Azure services and regions relevant to your deployments. Informs you of planned maintenance and service-impacting issues.
Tools for monitoring, analyzing, and optimizing Azure spending. Provides visibility into costs, helps set budgets, and generates alerts for overspending.
Enables you to enforce rules and governance across Azure subscriptions. Can be used to control resource types, locations, and configurations.
JSON files that define the structure and configuration of Azure resources. Used to automate deployments and ensure consistency.
Framework for defining sets of Azure resources, policies, and deployment sequences as reusable artifacts. Helps with governance and compliance.
Protects deployed resources from accidental modification or deletion. Can be applied at different levels (subscription, resource group, or individual resource).
The technologies and practices related to protecting Azure environments, managing user identities, and complying with regulatory standards.
Microsoft's cloud-based identity and access management service. Provides single sign-on, multi-factor authentication, and user/group management for cloud and on-premises applications.
Securely stores and manages secrets like keys, certificates, and connection strings for Azure applications.
Enables service providers to manage multiple Azure tenants from a single control plane, offering scalability and enhanced management.
Centralized security management platform for Azure. Provides threat protection, vulnerability assessment, workload protection, and security posture recommendations.
A cloud-native SIEM (Security Information and Event Management) and SOAR (Security Orchestration, Automation, and Response) solution. Helps detect, investigate, and respond to security threats.
Provides unified security management and threat protection for hybrid and multi-cloud workloads including Azure, on-premises, and other clouds.
Centralized portal for information on Microsoft's security, privacy, and compliance practices, including certifications and standards adherence.
Information used by applications, typically stored in databases. Examples include customer data, product catalogs, and transactional records.
Processing power and memory used to run applications. In Azure, common examples include virtual machines (VMs), containers, Azure Functions (serverless compute), and Azure App Service.

Services used to store various types of data in Azure. This includes Azure Blob Storage (objects), Azure Files (file shares), Azure Disks (block storage for VMs), and Azure Databases (e.g., SQL, Cosmos DB).
Software that performs specific tasks for users, ranging from productivity applications to enterprise business systems, built and deployed on Azure.
The ability of a system to handle increased workload by adding more resources (e.g., additional VMs, higher-tier database).
Closely related to scalability; the ability to dynamically add or remove resources based on current demand, optimizing resource usage and costs.
A design principle that prioritizes minimizing downtime. Achievable by using redundancy, fault tolerance techniques, and load balancing.
Deploying application components across multiple geographically dispersed regions for improved performance, availability, and disaster recovery.
An Azure Storage replication option that replicates data to a secondary region for protection against regional outages.
A variation of GRS offering read-access to data in the secondary region for additional scenarios.
Replicates data synchronously across three availability zones within a single Azure region to protect against zone-level failures.
The most basic Azure Storage replication option. Replicates data multiple times within a single data center in a single region.
Measures taken to ensure the restoration of systems and data after a disaster event (e.g., natural disaster, cyberattack)
The ability of a system to continue operating even when components fail. Achieved through redundancy and failover mechanisms.
Minimizing delays in data transmission between systems. Critical for real-time applications and interactive experiences.
The ability to adjust resources (e.g., compute, storage) up or down automatically based on changing workload demands.
A cloud computing model where the cloud provider manages infrastructure, scaling, and allocation of resources. Developers focus on code logic (e.g., Azure Functions, Logic Apps).

The Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) model is a conceptual framework that divides networking functions into seven layers: Physical, Data Link, Network, Transport, Session, Presentation, and Application.
Tools and interfaces used to interact with and administer Azure resources.
Web-based graphical interface for managing Azure resources. Provides a user-friendly way to create, configure, and monitor services.
A set of PowerShell cmdlets designed to work with and manage Azure resources. Azure PowerShell lets you perform administrative tasks from the command line, ideal for automation and scripting.
Azure's cross-platform command-line interface. Using the Azure CLI, you can execute commands across various Azure services through a terminal for managing and configuring resources.

The practice of strategically maximizing resource usage while minimizing costs on Azure. Cost optimization involves identifying unused resources, right-sizing services, and leveraging cost-saving options like Azure Reservations.
A purchasing option allowing you to reserve virtual machine capacity in Azure for one or three years. This upfront commitment leads to significant discounts compared to pay-as-you-go pricing.

A service in Azure enabling developers and testers to quickly provision development and testing environments. DevTest Labs help manage costs with features like quotas, auto-shutdown policies, and pre-built environments.

A service that lets you group and manage a set of identical, load-balanced Azure virtual machines. Scale sets allow you to automatically increase or decrease the number of VMs based on demand or predefined schedules.
A way to prepay for Azure resources (such as VMs, storage, databases) for a period of one or three years. This commitment results in significant cost savings compared to pay-as-you-go pricing.
